journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition

title-group.subtitle: A Case Report of Suspected Fat Overload Syndrome in Oral Refeeding

contrib-group.aff: Department of Medicine, Hospitalist Service, Brigham and Women’s Hospital, Boston, Massachusetts

author-notes.corresp: Arielle D. Macher, Brigham and Women’s Hospital, 75 Francis St, PBBB B-428, Boston, MA 02155, USA; e-mail: amacher@partners.org.

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2012 American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition
permissions.copyright-holder: The American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition

abstract.p: Refeeding syndrome has been observed in patients receiving nutrition after a prolonged period of malnourishment and is characterized by multiple metabolic derangements. Besides hypophosphatemia and hypoglycemia, lipemia has been described in association with parenteral nutrition administration to the malnourished. The authors describe one anorexic patient who developed lipemia during oral refeeding, followed by a precipitous drop in hematocrit suggestive of fat overload syndrome.

body.p: Hyperlipidemia has been reported in anorexia nervosa before hyperalimentation,1 and it is a known side effect of parenteral nutrition (PN) administration.2 However, little has been reported about lipemia in the setting of oral refeeding in the extremely malnourished. Our experience with this patient suggests that when treating the emaciated anorectic at risk of refeeding syndrome, close attention should be paid not only to serum electrolytes but also to serum lipids given a number of potentially adverse acute and chronic complications.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 20-year-old woman with no past medical history presented to a hospital-based clinic to establish primary care. She complained of a 23-kg weight loss over the preceding 4 months to a nadir weight of 34.5 kg in association with food anxiety, caloric obsession, overexercising behavior, and amenorrhea. The patient denied purging or laxative abuse. She was immediately referred to the emergency department due to vital sign abnormalities.

On examination, she was hypotensive at 84/60 mm Hg with a heart rate of 59, temperature of 35.7°C, respirations of 18, and oxygen saturation of 99% on room air. At a height of 162.6 cm, body mass index (BMI) was calculated to be 13.0 kg/m2. Physical exam was most notable for subcutaneous crepitus along the upper chest, which was confirmed by chest computed tomography (CT) visualizing air throughout the soft tissue spaces of both the thorax and abdomen, causing pneumomediastinum (see Figure 1) but no evidence of structural damage to the lung. Furthermore, an upper gastrointestinal series recommended by a thoracic surgery consult confirmed the absence of esophageal rupture. Her pneumomediastinum was thought to be spontaneous, associated with anorexia,3 and resolved with supportive care, including a 5-day course of prophylactic vancomycin, ciprofloxacin, and metronidazole to prevent mediastinitis. With the exception of hypophosphatemia and mildly elevated transaminases sometimes seen in anorexia and correlative to lower BMI,4 admission laboratory data were normal (see Table 1).

caption.p: Admission chest computed tomography with subcutaneous emphysema and severe pneumomediastinum.
Lab Values at Consecutive Hospital Days

fn.p: Dash signifies no laboratory data available.

ALT, alanine aminotransferase; AST, aspartate aminotransferase; Glu, glucose; HCT, hematocrit; HDL, high-density lipoprotein; kcal, kilocalorie; LDL, low-density lipoprotein; PO4, phosphate; TC, total cholesterol; Tri, triglycerides.

fn.label: d
fn.p: Transfused 1 unit of red blood cells.

sec.p: The patient’s caloric needs were calculated by the Fleisch equation to equal 1877 calories daily, encompassing a 1.25 standard activity factor for ambulation and 500 addition repletion calories for weight gain. Calorie counts were conducted daily and revealed that for the first 6 days of admission, the patient ate fewer than 900 calories, even less than her basic metabolic rate of 1101.4 kilocalories. After multiple discussions with psychiatry, nutrition, and the primary team, the patient acquiesced to increasing her intake, requesting food from home and on-site restaurants, which presented some difficulty in accurately assessing her consumption but was accepted by the medical team to increase compliance with weight gain goals. Over the subsequent days, the patient’s intake rapidly peaked, and on hospital day 8, after 2 days being ear or above caloric goal, the patient’s phosphate dropped from 3.6 to 1.9 mg/dL, requiring intravenous repletion. At this juncture, nutrition recommended stabilizing the patient’s oral intake; however, the patient herself continued to request outside food to maximize weight gain and consumption neared 3000 calories (see Table 1). The following day, her serum sample was noted by the lab to be grossly lipemic with mild hemolysis. Physical exam was unchanged but for low-grade temperatures up to 37.9°C and new intermittent sinus tachycardia with rates ranging upwards to the 120s. A fasting lipid panel was repeated, and triglycerides were found to have more than tripled to a total of 871 mg/dL.

The metabolic support team was consulted and recommended initiating levocarnitine 1 g per day to decrease hypertriglyceridemia by enhancing fatty acid metabolism through facilitation across the mitochondrial membrane.5 The triglycerides remained elevated above 500 mg/dL; however, her hematocrit dropped from 36.0% to a low of 21.1% (see Figure 2). An anemia workup guided by a hematology consult found guaiac-negative brown stool on multiple occasions; no ecchymotic changes to suggest hematoma formation, although bleeding into the area of the subcutaneous emphysema was not ruled out (repeat CT scans were not performed per patient request to avoid excessive radiation exposure); negative direct Coomb’s test and normal haptoglobin, fibrinogen, and iron levels; and elevated erythropoietin, vitamin B12, and folic acid. However, the patient did exhibit a mildly elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) at 325 U/L and an initially inadequate reticulocytosis with an index of 0.62%, which gradually increased appropriately to 5.13%. After 1 unit of packed red blood cells, the patient’s hematocrit improved, as did the triglycerides to <300 mg/dL with levocarnitine treatment. She was discharged several days later to an inpatient eating disorder unit.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Eating disorders, particularly anorexia nervosa, have long been associated with hyperlipidemia, and our patient was not an exception, with triglycerides noted to be 226 mg/dL on hospital day 5. The precise mechanism is not yet clearly defined, but the etiology is likely multifactorial, including decreased cholesterol and bile acid turnover due to starvation,1 decreased thyroid hormone and estrogen secretion,6 enhanced cholesterol metabolism,7 and inhibition of triglyceride catabolism.8 High cholesterol level, even in the starved patient, is not without potential adverse effect, as exemplified by the case report of a 39-year-old anorexic smoker who became hyperlipidemic during hyperalimentation and subsequently developed an inferior wall myocardial infarction during the sixth week of treatment.9 However, of the 6 case reports and cohort studies assessing lipid characteristics in anorectics, all reported normalization or trends toward normalization with refeeding.6-8,10-12

During starvation, insulin levels decrease and glucagon increases, with resulting gluconeogenesis from lipid and protein catabolism. With refeeding, insulin levels rebound, causing intracellular uptake of glucose, potassium, and phosphate and a reduction in lipid elimination capacity.13 Furthermore, insulin itself has a stimulatory effect on lipogenesis.14 In a study of 15 subjects, 11 of which were of normal BMI, 3 overweight, and 1 obese, all but one had rise of triglycerides when changed from a high-fat to high-carbohydrate diet. Higher insulin activity was associated with a greater triglyceride rise on a high-carbohydrate diet.15 These results were replicated by Goldrick et al,16 who fed lean but otherwise healthy young adults a high-caloric, high-carbohydrate diet, causing significant elevations in insulin and triglycerides; when returned back to a basic diet, concentrations of insulin and triglycerides began to fall.

Thus, our patient’s hypertriglyceridemia was likely due to increased insulin secretion during refeeding, particularly evident when her caloric intake was more than 1000 calories greater than her calculated requirements. Failure of other studies to detect worsening lipemia during refeeding in anorectics may be partially due to lipid panels not being checked serially over the first few days of treatment. Lipid analyses in patients receiving PN, on the other hand, have been studied in detail, with hypertriglyceridemia observed in 25%−50% of such patients.2 Pancreatitis, hepatic steatosis, and possible increased risk for atherosclerosis are the more commonly cited complications.17,18

Of greater concern is the rarer “fat overload syndrome” characterized by rather acute-onset hypertriglyceridemia in association with pyrexia, anemia, bleeding tendency, transaminitis, tachycardia, hypertension, and even fatal fat thrombi.18,19 Campbell et al20 described a 7-year-old who developed lipemia, fever, hematemesis, and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) elevation with PN and lipid infusion. With discontinuation of PN and lipid infusions, lipid levels fell to normal after 7 days and hematemesis resolved. A similar case was reported by Heyman et al21 of a 10-month-old girl admitted with fever, mucosal bleeding, and sclera jaundice while on PN with fat emulsions, where her serum was found to be grossly lipemic. Once PN was discontinued, bleeding ceased with clearance of lipemia on the fourth day. They postulated that lipemia results when lipoprotein lipase becomes saturated and fat cannot be cleared rapidly enough by the reticuloendothelial system. Interestingly, in a study of Lipomul intravenous (IV) fat emulsions to adult oncology patients requiring parenteral feeding, 14 of 15 developed acute anemia.22

One possible etiology of our patient’s precipitous hematocrit drop in association with hypertriglyceridemia, mild hemolysis, low-grade temperature, and tachycardia is that she developed a variant of fat overload syndrome, although this previously has only been reported with PN fat emulsions. After our patient’s rapid increase in caloric intake, she had classic signs of refeeding syndrome: hypophosphatemia and hypertriglyceridemia, consistent with increased insulin. Once her body adapted to 2000–3000 calories per day, her electrolytes stabilized, and her triglycerides fell below 300 mg/dL. The patient’s anemia appeared and then began to resolve over this same time course.

Our case suggests the need for scrupulous lipid monitoring in patients at risk for refeeding syndrome and raises the possibility of fat overload syndrome occurring in the oral refeeding of malnourished patients, even in the absence of parenteral feeding. Furthermore, it prompted changes at our own institution with establishment of eating disorder–specific treatment guidelines. Meals are now trayed by the kitchen in conjunction with registered dietician recommendations to maximize accuracy. Initial prescribed caloric requirements are still calculated through the Fleisch equation with the addition of an activity factor but are not uptitrated until the patient’s electrolytes have demonstrated stability. Thereafter, caloric intake is increased in 250 caloric increments until regular weight gain goals are met.

ack.p: We thank Megan McCullough, RD, LDN, CNSC, for her thoughtful assessment of the revised manuscript.
